sect2.para: BusyBox combines tiny versions of many common UNIX utilities into a single small executable. It provides replacements for most of the utilities you usually find in GNU fileutils, shellutils, etc. The utilities in BusyBox generally have fewer options than their full-featured GNU cousins; however, the options that are included provide the expected functionality and behave very much like their GNU counterparts.

sect2.title: Installation of BusyBox
sect2.para: Disable RPC support because of issues when building against Glibc:

screen.userinput: sed -e 's/\(CONFIG_FEATURE_HAVE_RPC\)=y/# \1 is not set/' \ -e 's/\(CONFIG_FEATURE_INETD_RPC\)=y/# \1 is not set/' -i .config

sect2.para: Instead of using the default DES method, use the more secure SHA-512 method of password encryption:
Disable simplified modutils and enable standard utilities for loading kernel modules:

screen.userinput: sed -e 's/\(CONFIG_MODPROBE_SMALL\)=y/# \1 is not set/' \ -e 's/# \(CONFIG_INSMOD\) is not set/\1=y/' \ -e 's/# \(CONFIG_RMMOD\) is not set/\1=y/' \ -e 's/# \(CONFIG_LSMOD\) is not set/\1=y/' \ -e 's/# \(CONFIG_FEATURE_LSMOD_PRETTY_2_6_OUTPUT\) is not set/\1=y/' \ -e 's/# \(CONFIG_MODPROBE\) is not set/\1=y/' \ -e 's/# \(CONFIG_FEATURE_MODPROBE_BLACKLIST\) is not set/\1=y/' \ -e 's/# \(CONFIG_DEPMOD\) is not set/\1=y/' \ -e 's/# \(CONFIG_FEATURE_CHECK_TAINTED_MODULE\) is not set/\1=y/' \ -e 's/# \(CONFIG_FEATURE_MODUTILS_ALIAS\) is not set/\1=y/' \ -e 's/# \(CONFIG_FEATURE_MODUTILS_SYMBOLS\) is not set/\1=y/' -i .config

porg -lD "install -v -m 755 busybox /bin" for program in cat echo pwd sh stty ; do porg -lD+ "ln -sfv busybox /bin/$program" ; done for program in addgroup adduser ash base64 basename blockdev bunzip2 \ bzcat bzip2 cal chgrp chmod chown chpasswd chroot chrt cksum cmp comm cp cpio \ cut date dc dd delgroup deluser depmod df diff dirname dmesg dnsdomainname \ dos2unix du egrep eject env expand expr false fdformat fdisk fgrep find flock \ fold free fsck.minix fstrim ftpd fuser getopt getty grep groups gunzip gzip \ halt hd head hexdump hostid hostname hwclock id ifconfig inetd init \ insmod install ionice iostat ip ipcrm ipcs kill killall killall5 klogd last \ linux32 linux64 ln logger login logname losetup ls lsmod \ lzcat lzma md5sum mdev mkdir mkdosfs mkfifo mkfs.minix mkfs.vfat mknod mkswap \ mktemp modinfo modprobe more mount mountpoint mpstat mv netstat nice nohup \ nslookup od passwd patch pgrep pidof ping ping6 pivot_root pkill pmap \ poweroff printenv printf ps pstree pwdx readlink readprofile realpath reboot \ renice rev rm rmdir rmmod route rtcwake runlevel script scriptreplay sed seq \ setarch setsid sha1sum sha256sum sha3sum sha512sum shuf sleep sort split stat \ su sulogin sum swapoff swapon switch_root sync sysctl syslogd tac tail tar \ tee telnet telnetd test tftp tftpd time timeout top touch tr traceroute \ traceroute6 true tty umount uname unexpand uniq unix2dos unlink unlzma unxz \ unzip uptime users uudecode uuencode vi vlock wall watch wc wget which who \ whoami xargs xz xzcat yes zcat ; do porg -lD+ "ln -sv busybox /bin/$program" ; done

sect2.title: Configuration
sect2.para: Choose a password for user root and set it by running:
Create a new /etc/syslog.conf file by running the following:

screen.userinput:
cat > /etc/syslog.conf << "EOF" # Begin /etc/syslog.conf
auth,authpriv.* /var/log/auth.log *.*;auth,authpriv.none /var/log/sys.log daemon.* /var/log/daemon.log kern.* /var/log/kern.log mail.* /var/log/mail.log user.* /var/log/user.log *.emerg *
# End /etc/syslog.conf EOF ls /etc/syslog.conf | porg -lD+

seglistitem.seg: addgroup, adduser, ash, base64, basename, blockdev, bunzip2, busybox, bzcat, bzip2, cal, cat, chgrp, chmod, chown, chpasswd, chroot, chrt, cksum, cmp, comm, cp, cpio, cut, date, dc, dd, delgroup, deluser, depmod, df, diff, dirname, dmesg, dnsdomainname, dos2unix, du, echo, egrep, eject, env, expand, expr, false, fdformat, fdisk, fgrep, find, flock, fold, free, fsck.minix, fstrim, ftpd, fuser, getopt, getty, grep, groups, gunzip, gzip, halt, hd, head, hexdump, hostid, hostname, hwclock, id, ifconfig, inetd, init, insmod, install, ionice, iostat, ip, ipcrm, ipcs, kill, killall, killall5, klogd, last, linux32, linux64, ln, logger, login, logname, losetup, ls, lsmod, lzcat, lzma, md5sum, mdev, mkdir, mkdosfs, mkfifo, mkfs.minix, mkfs.vfat, mknod, mkswap, mktemp, modinfo, modprobe, more, mount, mountpoint, mpstat, mv, netstat, nice, nohup, nslookup, od, passwd, patch, pgrep, pidof, ping, ping6, pivot_root, pkill, pmap, poweroff, printenv, printf, ps, pstree, pwd, pwdx, readlink, readprofile, realpath, reboot, renice, rev, rm, rmdir, rmmod, route, rtcwake, runlevel, script, scriptreplay, sed, seq, setarch, setsid, sh, sha1sum, sha256sum, sha3sum, sha512sum, shuf, sleep, sort, split, stat, stty, su, sulogin, sum, swapoff, swapon, switch_root, sync, sysctl, syslogd, tac, tail, tar, tee, telnet, telnetd, test, tftp, tftpd, time, timeout, top, touch, tr, traceroute, traceroute6, true, tty, umount, uname, unexpand, uniq, unix2dos, unlink, unlzma, unxz, unzip, uptime, users, uudecode, uuencode, vi, vlock, wall, watch, wc, wget, which, who, whoami, xargs, xz, xzcat, yes, and zcat

listitem.para: Creates a new group or adds a user to a group with the given name.
Creates a new user or adds a user to a group with the given name.
Is the most complete and most pedantically correct shell included with BusyBox.
Encodes and decodes data according to the RFC 3548 specification.
Strips any path and a given suffix from a file name.
Calls block device ioctls from the command line.
Decompresses bzipped files.
Combines many common Unix utilities into a single executable.
Decompresses bzipped files to standard output.
Compresses files with bzip2 algorithm.
Displays a simple calendar.
Concatenates files to standard output.
Changes the group ownership of files and directories.
Changes the permissions of each file to the given mode.
Changes the user and/or group ownership of files and directories.
Updates user passwords in batch mode.
Runs a command with the specified directory as the root directory.
Changes scheduling priority and class for a process.
Calculates the CRC32 checksums of files.
Compares two files and reports whether or in which bytes they differ.
Compares two sorted files.
Copies files.
Copies files into and out of a cpio archive.
Prints selected fields from each input file.
Displays the current time in the given format, or sets the system time.
Is a tiny reverse polish notation calculator.
Copies a file with converting and formatting.
Deletes a group from the system or a user from a group with the given name.
Deletes a user with the given name from the system.
Creates a dependency file based on the symbols it finds in the existing set of kernel modules.
Prints file system usage statistics.
Compares files line by line and outputs the differences between them.
Strips the non-directory suffix from a file name.
Prints or controls the kernel ring buffer.
Shows domain part of the system's fully qualified host name.
Converts files from DOS to Unix format.
Summarizes disk space used for each file and/or directory.
Displays the given strings.
Prints lines matching an extended regular expression.
Ejects removable media.
Runs a command in a specified environment.
Converts tabs to spaces.
Evaluates expressions.
Returns an exit status code indicating failure.
Formats a floppy disk.
Manipulates the paritition table of the given device.
Prints lines matching a list of fixed strings.
Searches for files and performs actions on them.
Acquires a file lock and then executes a command with the lock held.
Wraps the lines in the given files.
Displays the amount of free and used system memory.
Checks MINIX file system.
Discards unused blocks on a mounted filesystem.
Is an anonymous FTP server.
Finds processes which use given files or ports.
Parses options in the given command line.
Opens a tty port, prompts for a login name, and then invokes the login program.
Prints lines matching a basic regular expression.
Reports the group memberships of user.
Decompresses gzipped files.
Compresses files with gzip algorithm.
Halts the system.
Is an alias for hexdump -C.
Prints the first ten lines of each given file.
Dumps the given file in hexadecimal or in another given format.
Reports the numeric identifier of the host.
Shows or sets system host name.
Reads or sets the system's hardware clock.
Reports information about the current user or specified user.
Configures a network interface.
Listens for network connections and launches programs.
Is the first process started during boot.
Loads the specified kernel module into the running kernel.
Copies files and sets attributes.
Gets or sets I/O priority and class for a program.
Reports CPU and I/O statistics.
Shows and manipulates network routing, devices, policy routing and tunnel.
Removes the given Inter-Process Communication resource.
Provides IPC status information.
Sends signals to processes.
Sends a signal to given processes.
Send a signal to all processes outside current session.
Intercepts and logs kernel messages.
Shows listing of the last users that logged into the system.
Changes reported architecture to 32bit and sets linux32 personality flags.
Changes reported architecture to 64bit and sets linux64 personality flags.
Makes links between files.
Writes the given message into the system log.
Begins a new session on the system.
Reports the current user's login name.
Sets up and controls loop devices.
Lists directory contents.
Lists currently loaded kernel modules.
Decompresses LZMA compressed files to standard output.
Compresses or decompresses files using the LZMA format.
Prints or checks MD5 checksums.
Creates and dynamically updates device files.
Creates directories with the given names.
Creates FAT32 file systems.
Creates a named pipe.
Creates MINIX file systems.
Creates FAT32 file systems.
Creates device nodes with the given names.
Initializes the given block device to be used as a swap area.
Creates a temporary file with name based on template.
Examines an object file associated with a kernel module and displays any information that it can glean.
Uses a dependency file, created by depmod, to automatically load relevant modules.
Views files or stdin one screenful at a time.
Mounts a file system.
Checks if the directory is a mountpoint.
Writes activities for each available processor.
Moves or renames files or directories.
Displays networking information.
Runs a program with modified scheduling priority.
Runs a command immune to hangups.
Queries the nameserver for the IP address of the given host.
Dumps files in octal and other formats.
Changes the password for a user account.
Modifies files according to a patch file.
Displays processes selected by regex pattern.
Looks up processes based on their name.
Sends echo-request packets to network hosts.
Is a version of ping for IPv6 networks.
Makes the given file system the new root file system of the current process.
Sends a signal to processes selected by regex pattern.
Displays detailed process memory usage.
Halts the system and shuts off power.
Prints the environment.
Prints the given arguments according to the given format.
Shows list of processes.
Displays running processes as a tree.
Reports the name of the current working directory.
Reports the current working directory of a process.
Reports the value of the given symbolic link.
Reads kernel profiling information.
Prints the resolved path of the given file.
Reboots the system.
Alters the priority of running processes.
Reverses the lines of a given file.
Removes files or directories.
Removes directories if they are empty.
Unloads kernel modules from the running kernel.
Edits kernel routing tables.
Enters a system sleep state until specified wakeup time.
Finds the current and previous system runlevel.

Plays back typescripts using timing information.
Filters and transforms text files in a single pass.
Prints a sequence of numbers within a given range and with a given increment.
Changes reported architecture in a new program environment and sets personality flags.
Runs the given program in a new session.
Is an alias for ash.
Prints or checks SHA1 checksums.

Runs program and displays resource usage when it exits.

Count lines, words, and bytes for each given file.

Reports the user name associated with the current effective user ID.
Runs a given command to a list of files.
Compresses or decompresses files using the XZ format.
Decompresses XZ compressed files to standard output.
Repeatedly outputs 'y' or a given string until killed.
Decompresses gzipped files to standard output.
